text: good morning everyone I'm Joshua Margolis I'm a professor here in the organizational behavior unit and it's a
pleasure to welcome you to uh the second panel in our Summit
um as you are about to hear um you will understand why I feel a distinct
privilege to uh be moderating this session with three of our distinguished
alumni as you will soon here each of them has exemplified the mission of
Harvard Business School each of them has exercised leadership that has made a difference in the
world and each of them has done so in the face of some extreme circumstances
which we refer to in this session as dealing with the unexpected and in a few minutes you'll
hear from each of them about their experiences and about some of the lessons that they have drawn this panel
was put together with a simple but Stark originating idea life
happens when students graduate from Harvard Business School and set out to pursue their aspirations and their plans
and their highest imagined achievements the unexpected unfolds in their lives
and in their careers but all too infrequent are the opportunities to
acknowledge the unexpected let alone to discuss the unexpected or to reflect
upon it and share the lessons that we take away and this session is designed to start a conversation about the
unexpected as it arises in different shapes and forms in our lives and what we can learn from one another about how
to navigate the unexpected in our lives let me take a few minutes to introduce
our three panelists and then to let you know how we hope to run today's session
so first we'll hear from Lisa caroy MBA 1994 section A I'm proud to say a
section made of mine and a uh and a friend uh Lisa is the head of global
Capital markets for Bank of America Merl Lynch she's a member of the global corporate and Investment Banking
operating committee and the capital commitment committee she's also executive sponsor for the women's
Leadership Council in global banking and markets Lisa has worked in Investment
Banking since receiving her ba from Columbia University she worked for three investment Banks before arriving here on
campus to get her MBA and she's now a trustee at Columbia chairing the alumni
Affairs and development committee she's a proud New Yorker living on the upper west side with her husband David a
journalist and therefore children next we will hear from Melissa
Wexner MBA 1982 section B Melissa is a writer speaker and advocate in the area
of Substance Abuse Prevention and treatment and and she teaches high school math she's the author of a book
about her daughter's struggle with drugs about which you will hear in quite inspiring fashion in just a few minutes
Melissa attended Welsley college and earned her Bachelor's in economics from MIT a masters in systems engineering
from the University of Houston and then worked for kico after graduating with her MBA from Harvard she worked at huet
Packard in Apollo computer and in 1988 she founded cernetic a high
performance networking company that was later acquired by 3om she left high-tech in 2000 and switched careers to teaching
and she's been quite active in the Harvard Business School alumni association of Boston third we'll hear
from Kathy juy MBA 1985 section A Kathy is the founder and chief executive
officer of the multiple Myoma Research Foundation and the multiple Myoma research Consortium she has more than
two decades of experience in the pharmaceutical industry and previously held senior positions at GD surl and at
Merc she's received many awards for her Innovative leadership most recently being named to the 2011 time 100 list of
the most influential people she's received the Harvard Business School alumni Achievement Award and the
healthcare business women's Association Woman of the Year award her efforts have been featured on
NBC CBS FOX News and CNN and her work has been profiled in the wall Street
Journal the New Yorker Harvard Business review The Economist the New York Times and Forbes and Kathy currently serves on
the president's Council of advisers on science and technology so beyond these
impressive achievements let me explain why we asked these three women if they
would serve on this panel um the first is because of the range of unexpected
challenges that they represent what you will hear in their stories and their
experiences reflects the range of unexpected challenges that our alumni encounter in their lives everything from
the personal to the professional from economic shocks to
Health crisis from The Unexpected that grips our organizations and our careers
to the unexpected that grips our families and our children you will hear it represented in the stories the
experiences that they share but perhaps more important we asked these three women to serve on this panel because you
will hear in their stories that the way they Rose to these challenges the way they Rose to these unexpected events
holds lessons for all of us so what we are going to do is we'll hear from each
of them in succession Lisa will share her experiences then we'll hear from Melissa and then from Kathy um they'll
go they'll take about 10 minutes a piece to share their experiences and to distill a few lessons that they take
away and then we're hoping hoping to open it up to discussion and to questions with that Lisa thank you um
it's an honor to be here and speak uh to you and with you on the unexpected just a couple things before I dive in um I'm
going to speak about a professional challenge because that's what I was asked to speak about but I certainly acknowledge that our lives are much
bigger than what we do in our careers and that no matter what challenge I faced professionally it pales in
comparison to anything that impacts uh your health your family or or the
broader world so with that said um certainly the biggest professional challenge of my career
was the end of Mara Lynch and the financial crisis and our ultimate merger with Bank of America and just to take
you back uh to 2007 um I had already been at maril Lynch for 15 years um I joined the firm
at of business school and I was very deliberate in choosing the firm in fact in somewhat of an oldfashioned way I
picked a firm that I plan to be at for a very very long time maybe 25 years or more and I picked the firm largely
because of the culture and the people and the spirit of Entrepreneurship and I absolutely loved it um and and uh had
had a bright career to that point and was very devoted to my colleagues who were uh very much like my family as well
and they were with me uh in in force when I got married they were with me when my father passed away while I was a
young associate um and really my um my role and my friendships at the firm were
were critical to my life and so in the late part of 2007 I got a call from our president who said that um he needed me
to get involved in helping the company raise um Equity capital and for those of you who are familiar with financial
institutions capital and liquidity are really the lifeblood of a financial institution and that was really an alarm
that that something was not right and that we uh candidly were in trouble and uh the situation was potentially dire
and I felt an enormous weight um there was a small group of us working on this over the ensuing uh nine months or so we
ended up doing our first deal over Christmas in 2007 and we did several other deals um over the next several
quarters um I felt enormous pressure I was in a situation where it was very confidential so I didn't even talk about
it with my friends or my husband even my partners at work um some of the deals in and of themselves were a success but uh
every few months we would get another call that in fact we needed more Capital we needed to find more investors and I really felt the weight of 40,000 jobs
and and the families and the related businesses that were connected to the firm um in September of
2008 um there was an announcement over a very challenging weekend with the end of Leman brothers that Bank of America was
going to merge uh by Mara Lynch and on the one hand I was quite relieved because I knew it was a good thing to be
part of a bigger and hopefully stronger institution but also the challenges of a merger and um from a personal point of
view I didn't know if I had a job uh for 91 days I was seven and eight months pregnant with twins at that point so
perhaps not an ideal time to be thinking about a job search and I was also very focused on my team and what would happen
in the integration um and what what do you convey during a period of tremendous uncertainty in the broader markets as
well as in this company as it was about to combine and um as you would now know
um it's been four plus years um since the the merger Bank of America and Maryland's merged on January 1st of of
09 um and we're embarking on our fifth year but um from a um business point of
view I think uh um it's been a success but certainly it has created many challenges and so Joshua had asked us to
share sort of what did we learn from this crisis or this uh unexpected Challenge and I would share three things
um first um there's a famous Haitian proverb that speaks to mountains Beyond
mountains that you get through something very difficult and there's something behind it that's equally difficult another tall mountain and that this
period felt very much like that we would do a deal and think that we'd fortifi the company that we were in great shape and that we could get back to delivering
for clients and doing deals and and running the dayto day and yet uh each quarter we ended up having yet another
mountain or another desire for um more capital and it was very daunting and what it made me realize is that you have
to take things one day at a time to persevere and that um you do the best you can each day and you'll get to the
next challenge and and um and and continue going and so not look at the uh
the big picture and get two to daunted by what was ahead related to that um the second lesson that I learned in uh Jim
Collins book good to great he spoke about the Stockdale Paradox and for those of you who are not familiar um
Admiral Stockdale um was a p in Vietnam for 8 years and he spoke so eloquently
about the fact that there were many other prisoners of War who frankly didn't make it and those were by and
large the people that said I'll be home by Thanksgiving or I'll be home by Christmas I'll be home by my kids's
birthday and what Stockdale said is you can't be focused on the N term I'm going
to get out of here you just need to have confidence in the long term that you'll Prevail in the long term and Prevail May mean different things for different
people for me it meant being part of a firm that was sustaining and strong even thriving and that I feel comfortable in
the culture and uh could deliver for clients and colleagues but really having that faith in the great long term and
particularly post the merger announcement and during the period of integration I really thought about that
because I couldn't convey a clear picture on the Nar term but I certainly could convey that over the long term
things would get better and then finally and most most importantly compassion um
to give a sense at the time of the merger I was um managing a business that had 77 employees um and coincidentally
the Bank of America team that did the same part of the business was also 77 people so 154 um post layoffs we went
all the way down to 79 people and so um that was really one of the hardest
things I've ever been a part of and you realize that no matter what you need to treat treat people like the people they
are their brothers their fathers their sons their mothers their cousins their neighbors and um treat them with dignity
and respect and um the human element of that obviously goes well beyond the numbers and so um I think we've all been
through a tremendous amount um and there were obviously layoffs even post that period I hope we're through it now but
that is something that um even a Harvard MBA and all of my experience to that point had not prepared me for so with
that I'm going to pause and we'll turn over to Melissa thanks Lisa thanks for uh thanks for coming for
having us um after graduating from HBS I had a wonderful run in Hightech six
years out when I was two months pregnant with my third child I co-founded the technology company and our family also
moved to a larger house two months before our second daughter was born Amy arrived between our startups fifth and
sixth employees um new company new house new baby it's amazing what you can do in
your early 30s on 5 hours of sleep a night um and despite a stint of postpartum depression which I never
heard talked about at HBS uh those years proved to be some of the most satisfying creative and Foundation Building of my
life Amy was five when my startup was acquired by 3com and 11 when I left high-tech and then started teaching high
school math full-time I enrolled her my school for what would be a 4-year roller
coaster of our three kids for personality was was the most like mine and parenting her was not easy in
addition to being incredibly bright she was also extremely social and I didn't have the street smarts to know all of
what that meant having spent most of my life as a nerd as her behavior became more
challenging we had her tested and she was diagnosed with depression anxiety low self-esteem and later add and
despite starting counseling she started cutting in ninth grade using marijuana the summer before 10th was already using
cocaine as a sophomore and first tried heroin at 17 I'll never forget the day she arrived
a cross country practice high from smoking weed and we had to meet with the principal then two hours later I had to
put on my best game face uh for the five classes worth of parents uh attending
back to school night most of whom had daughters on the cross country team there was no HBS to prepare me for that
surreal evening I found the prescription painkiller vicadin and Amy's purse
during junior year having no idea how serious a signal that was but when she had a positive tox screen for cocaine I
thought I need an action plan but I'm not sure my HBS approach was all that
effective dealing with a progressive disease we worked with a variety of professionals but most were convinced
that she was experimenting and when she started college her academics would Prevail I was heartened when she
transferred from St Louis University to Boston College's nursing program but on
November 16th 2009 I met with her in her drug counselor and learned that I was
the mother of a heroin addict but Amy wanted to go to treatment
but she would not be able to finish the first semester of her junior year six days later she began her week of detox
then four weeks of rehab she moved to a residential treatment facility and a few
days later snuck in drugs she fatally overdosed on the day
after Christmas week shy of her 21st birthday and this was her High School
ring and her favorite necklace and the facility did not have Naran the drug that can be sprayed up
the nose to reverse an overdose this could have saved my daughter's
life nobody expected Amy to die she was Bright Beautiful athletic had a loving
family career goals good health insurance and so many wonderful friends
she even referred to me as a loving workaholic I thought that his parents
who abstained from illegal substances we were well-educated role models and that somehow our family might be immune
wrong in fact one of my HBS colleagues came to Amy's wake and confided that
their son was a recovering heroin addict shortly there after we started a family
support group for addiction conduit through the HBS Association of Boston at a time when conventional
wisdom says not to make any major decisions I decided that I needed to scale back my new job to halftime Amy
had been on my case to leave that position for several months when she invited me to the Paul McCartney concert
at Fenway Park the August before she died I declined because we were in crunch season at work but the school
president would not accommodate my request to go halftime and I resigned 2 months after Amy died how cruel that my
exit strategy ended up being my daughter's death that door closing opened others I
was fortunate that I had the financial Foundation to pause from the paid Workforce most parents don't have that
option I could mother my then 24-year-old daughter who was shattered at the loss of her little sister
I was conscious that just because my daughter died of an overdose did not mean I had to shift Focus to work in
that area in fact sometimes I long to go back to a corporate cubicle where I could hide behind a screen if I was
having a bad day I began telling Amy's story she left
us the gift of the journals she wrote in rehab which I published last summer when
Amy died several people said you should start a foundation but having done a startup I knew how much work that is and
would be and I've rather spent my time trying to figure out who is already
heading up effective efforts and where I might join forces I've been writing speaking and advocating especially for
Naran knowing that feels right to me and when it no longer makes sense I'll
stop I don't have to tell you that every individual deals with every unexpected
situation differently but in going through A parents worst nightmare I realized that I could just as easily be
curled up in bed still unable to function so I don't think of myself as a role model I can just speak to my
experience to date I was booed by the friendships I'd maintained High School classmates my
Saturday running group the hbsab uh programs committee my former
students all of whom knew Amy my corporate colleagues in fact the
friendships I'd formed in the workplace much like Lisa have remained among the
strongest one colle colleague wrote the original music to the lyrics I created out of Amy's journals and another
recorded the audio book in her Studio my HBS training also makes me
increasingly concerned about the business Community coming to grips with the enormity of this epidemic and its
threat to our nation's security and economic competitiveness and how some of our best
business Minds Market a toxic culture to our children including the synthetic marijuana and candy-like tobacco
products you can buy at a convenience store the cost and opportunity costs of
the epidemic in health care criminal justice system and productivity are
staggering consider the case of the storage company in Ohio having trouble finding enough job candidates who can
pass a drug test or the company whose purchasing manager was buying extra
coffee in electronics than selling them on on eBay raising $100,000 to support
his painkiller addiction after Amy died former colleagues opened up with their stories
that we'd never talked about the CEO who had to send their kid to a Wilderness Program because of substance abuse and
attempted suicide the designer now raising her granddaughters because her
daughter killed herself after years of battling alcohol and drugs the top manager functioning with several heroin
addicted siblings the marketing Guru who hid his cocaine addiction from his parents for over a
decade I could go on and on I'm still learning about the
complexities of this scorge from the geopolitical to the heart of families I'm still figuring out where I
can uniquely add value I feel like this time of my life should be the most integrative period to make a positive
difference currently I'm teaching high school math the wonderful school where Amy went wanted me back part-time and
would love to have me back full-time but I'm finishing a second book this one for teens and young adults which is a
transcription of Amy's adolescent journals I continue to attend nanon
family group meetings and tell Amy's story to students parents Educators and clinicians and I talk individually with
neighbors and strangers and alums who seek me out I was humbled to realize that I was
powerless over my daughter's disease but I also felt really let down by so many of the professionals I dealt with I
have to cut myself the slack to know that I did the best I could with what I
knew at the time but I was clueless about so much especially how expensive
synthetic heroin I.E prescription painkillers are today's gateway to cheap
illegal heroin and that's why I'm passionate about sharing Amy's story and will be happy to share more of what I've
learned during the Q&A or after the session thank
you thanks so um so far you've heard a little bit about um challenges on the
career side um and then of course challenges um family and social and my job was just to help you to understand
what happens when you face a challenge yourself and it becomes a bit of a health issue because it definitely does
have impact on your family and your job and what you end up doing with all of that um so I thought I would just share my
story with you help you to understand how I overcame some of those obstacles and then give you uh three key takeaways
that I had from the journey so to walk you through my story I have to take you back always to when I was 37 years old
and um I will never really forget this time it was actually Christmas time and I was putting up our tree uh with my
husband Paul who was a an HBS classmate and we were literally putting this tree
up and I remember looking at him and going oh my God gosh we really are doing so great like we just bought this
beautiful home we had a little one-year-old girl wandering around with us and we both absolutely loved our jobs
and by the time we took that tree down and we're packing all the ornaments up I didn't know whether I would ever be
taking that box out of the attic again I had been diagnosed with um cancer it's
called multiple Myoma um when I was diagnosed it was 100% fatal and nobody
had ever lived more than 3 years years with the disease and I can tell you at that point everything that I was doing
just stopped you just stop everything you don't talk to your boss you don't even think about going into work you're
just going I don't know what just happened to my life um but clearly I'm
still sitting here and I'm 54 years old so some good things um happen through all of this and to walk you through the
story I have to help you to understand where I went personally and then where I also went
professionally personally I think I was incredibly lucky um because at a time
like that when you've been told um and they look you in the eye and say you are going to die get your life in order and
get your will written and get close to your family um you either pull the covers up over your head or you decide
you're going to fight and I was really lucky to have this little girl that was running into my bedroom every morning
with this big smile on her face and it never even dawned on me that I would do anything except fight to to live long
longer to be with her um since she was one at the time I kept thinking uh you know I'll probably be gone by the time
she turns four so I thought if I could just extend my life till she's five I had heard that that's when children
really start to remember their mom and that was my vision my vision was that simple it was a new vision in my life I
was just going to do whatever I could to have this little one remember me and that was good enough um the second thing
I did personally was I lived in small increments and again I had no choice because I was going um to the doctors
and every month they would draw my blood and if it was holding the cancer protein was holding it meant I got a reprieve
for another month and if it didn't that meant that I was going to be going in for a bone Mar transplant and um you
know I might make it I might not make it but again when you have a little one it's so amazing what you see in a month
like all of a sudden it was a new tooth or a new word and like I said oh my goodness that was like another great milestone so living in these little
Windows was was was okay by me and and then the third thing I realized is when you live with a death sentence you take
risk and so at the same time that I was interviewing all of my oncologists I
really wanted her to have a buddy you know I'd always planned on having more than one children I am an identical twin
I always had a sidekick and I just decided you know what I know it's crazy the doctors thought I was nuts but I
decided to go through in vitro and go through lots of several inv vitros and see if I could pull it off and and give
her a sibling um and if that was the last thing I again that was like a home run and so my life was going on like
this and while all of that was happening um the insurance was also through me and
so I had 300 people reporting to me and I I do remember the madness of it all trying to get the shots through the
invitro and standing in lines and then running to meetings where it was 200 people and then running to the
oncologist and trying to figure out a plan but you know what you kind of you just keep moving like like these just
one step at a time you keep moving so my personal life was moving along in that direction and then simultaneously
again I think you get back to the relationships and the people that love you I did have to walk away from my job
running worldwide operations for a major pharmaceutical company where my dream was to be the first woman president at
surl and um I knew I had to walk away but the company was great and I have to
say everybody around me that had worked with me at MC or surl at all the agencies all reached out and they were
trying to send money in checks and saying let's at least get Research into this really uncommon disease and see if
we can help you and that became the start of the multiple myama Research Foundation where these amazing
relationships Lifting me and I can't tell you that the friends from HBS my husband's classmates and mine were
really the start of our foundation and so I again I started saying okay let me
see if I can have a vision of bringing scientists into this uncommon disease and jump start what we needed to get
things going and again working in short-term increments cuz I didn't think
I would ever live long enough to run a major Foundation my short-term increments were well let's get the
scientists in okay let's build a tissue Bank okay let's build a clinical Network and do phase one and two trials okay now
we'll do genomic sequence saying oh you know what now I see another obstacle let's Force everybody to give up intellectual property and put all of
their tools out into the public domain because nobody's doing that and here it is years later um multiple Myoma as a
cancer has seen more drugs approved by FDA than any other cancer in the country
we have become the absolute gold standard in how you run a nonprofit and
my life is really speaking on the road and working with other amazing leaders of cystic fibrosis or Michael J fox
where we are changing not only cancer but the entire nonprofit sector and
again I think we ended up doing that with this tremendous sense of urgency I think because you know you're always
trying to save people's lives and when you're talking talking to patients that are all dying it's not just myom it's
pancreatic cancer and liver cancer you do live your life with a lot of urgency and you do take a lot of risk because I
really have nothing to lose people would say to me oh my God Kathy the Mayo Clinic is going to be so mad at you or
Dana haror is going to get so upset because you're breaking the mold of how academic Centers do research and I I
kind of look at I said you know as long as we're professional it's okay like we have to break the mold somebody's got to
break the mold the the way we do cancer research today is so unbelievably broken and archaic that somebody has to take a
stand on it on behalf of patients so I now can look at my life
and say you know where where did I land you know can I look back now and say um
you know have we done things well and I have to say I've been incredibly
incredibly lucky yes I did have to go through a grueling bone Mar transplant with my sister and um I wouldn't wish
that on anybody but I have been on every drug that our foundation has released
and while I am personally grateful for that I'm more grateful for the fact that we've literally saved tens of thousands
of patients lives um with these therapies I had been married to that same Harvard classmate for 25 years and
I took that survey and everything that I could have said of marrying well I'll tell you it was it was at least 50% of
the game for me I could not have asked for a better partner in my life um my
daughter Nicole that little one-year-old girl is now a freshman at Boston College
and um a business major who I think wants to follow in her mom's footsteps which is just amazing to me and yes she
does have a sidekick her little brother who's a sophomore in high school and I found out last night he pitched his
first no hitter you know I schol I missed it oh so but you know what um
it's all still good because you know he knows I I'd never miss his games and um you know they know they really do know
why I'm here and um I think at the end of the day I can look back at my life and say okay I didn't
become the first woman president of a pharmaceutical company I I kind of wish that I had but at the end of the day I
say you know what one and two of us will be diagnosed with cancer and one and three of us will die and if I can look
back on my life and say that I made it better for anybody and everybody um that
has to deal with these devastating diseases I say thank goodness so um
what do I what do I want to share with you I think the three things that I want to share with you are number one um you
can look at your life and it's all about happiness I had to reset the vision of my life you know it went from you know
this beautiful house outside of Chicago and you know having you know several children and being the president too you
know what I'm going to take a different path now it's it's going to be you know hoping my daughter um you know I get to
see her to kindergarten and then you know keep moving and it's okay to set a new vision for your life I think the
best thing I ever did and I say having cancer you have an excuse to go sit down with your husband and talk to counselors
because I certainly wasn't going to leave him with the mess of I'd like to have another child and by the way I'm going to die so I'm going to leave you
with that I mean everything we did we did with a plan and help and support and
trying to help us to understand well if we do do this then we should move and we should move to where our family is and
that means you're selling your company and if we sell your company there were so many other pieces but trying to
figure it out together and getting help to figure that out was the best thing that we ever did I think the second
piece and and Lisa talked about this too is you don't have to transform your entire life sometimes it's making the
small adjustments like I said you know a month at a time was how I was living and
um you'd be amazed at the small things you can do that you say you know what I actually feel happier now I really feel
like my life is in a better place right now and it's okay to make those small changes and then celebrate them because
you really you really do want to celebrate the moments that you get and the third thing I say to everybody is
don't don't wait for a crisis I mean I think the three of us are really the example of that don't wait for a crisis
in your life to make it better you know take that chance and do something today
that's going to make your life better because the rest of your life is not promised to you in any way and the last
piece that we were asked to speak on is um did Harvard prepare you in some way
for this and I I can tell you Harvard completely prepared me for this and the reason for that is I came to Harvard
never having taken a business class I was a Premed major accepted to medical school who decided to take a shift all I
knew was about the KB cycle and biology I didn't know any when the people gave me the cases I was like oh my God and I
will tell you first year I was going to leave I just I couldn't believe I was here I surrounded by all these business
people and Ben Shapiro um sat down with me and said you know what you've got a great technology background we kill to
have people that know science like you know science please stay we are here to help you and I did stay and I was
forever grateful for the support that Harvard gave me I was grateful for Harvard taking me out of my comfort zone
because I'm always outside my comfort zone today I'm always duking it out with academic centers or biotech firms or
different people and you know what I'm okay with that I I really am and I think third is the network that Harvard has
built for me I know for some people they say I don't really hear from Harvard unless I'm I'm getting you know a
request for funding my life with Harvard has not been like that at all in the last six months I've been back up here
on their healthc care board I did a program with them that was Harvard Business School match with Harvard Medical School um I come back up in May
where we're doing a program with Bill Salman and Richard Hames on how do you do deal structures when you're doing
Venture philanthropy and it's cystic fibrosis and Micha and we we bring everybody back together and we do our
own case studies but that was an idea we brought to them I don't think we should you know wait all the time to say well
what's the faculty doing for me sometimes if you've got a great idea they'll jump on it and now we've made
that into an annual program we write white papers we're doing more case studies around it and I'd say it's it's
been amazingly joyful so I have nothing but good things to say I think also you
know marrying you're you're the best guy I could marry that just happened to be here um I think that's also made my life
unbelievably unbelievably good as well thank you all um before we open it uh
for questions i' I'd like to um ask you all uh one starting question which is
what might HBS do to equip our students the next generation of students um to
handle the unexpected in in their lives are there any things that you'd suggest
that we think about doing here at the school to prepare our students as they go out to live their lives I mean I
think a lot of our cases just our business as usual and the crises are all
business crises but in fact um it's the personal crises that are going to be keeping yourself your employees you know
awake at night and I think a big problem is just having the introduction having
the language to talk about these things so cases that talk about something that
goes below the surface um so you can understand you know well gee this the CEO is trying to do a merger and at the
same time you know their daughter has needing disorder you know so you know it's supposed to fly here but they've
got to take their daughter to treatment um something about um you know the
reality of depression in the workforce and and even you know within the MBA program getting culted the culture of
the sections to be more sensitive to gee what do I look for to see if a classmate may be at risk how do I talk talk about
this where are the resources so just being able to start the conversations I think would be a huge step yeah I think
the case studies can be you know incredibly helpful and I mean some of them can talk about you know why people
landed where they landed you know and it it is always interesting there there are a lot of great Alum you know like I I I
listen to Lisa talk and I go how do she four K four children you know so we end up you know there are situations where
you know Lisa didn't end up talking about that but it's probably a really interesting Dynamic of how do you pull
those things off you know we have another classmate you know Katie Hood who was running Michael J fox she had to
